title: Citi weighs into Funlab, says 'better placed' than Ardent
text:
Citi's equities research analysts have told clients initial public offering-hopeful Funlab Group is better bet than the already-listed Ardent Leisure.

In a report sent to fund managers on Wednesday morning, the sponsor broker compared Funlab to ASX-listed Ardent which owns Dreamworld and Main Event in the United States and is well covered by local small caps investors.

"We consider Funlab as better placed than Ardent Leisure, which currently operates US-based Main Event and previously owned the Australian bowling-anchored Kingpin and AMF Bowling brands," Citi's analysts, led by Sam Teeger, said in their report Reinventing entertainment.

"This is due to i) Strike's significantly higher LFL sales growth compared to Main Event over FY17 to FY19, ii) lower competition in the Australian out-of-home entertainment market relative to the US, iii) Funlab's strong innovation track record, and iv) Funlab's venues and less reliant on bowling relative to Main Event and Kingpin."

Citi's pitch came as fellow sponsor broker JPMorgan was also talking up the company's prospects.

Citi said Funlab's Australian leisure peers were trading at a median of 19.7-times on a 2020 financial year price-to-earnings basis, and compared it to local retailers with rollout stories including Baby Bunting and Lovisa.
description: Citi's equities research analysts have told clients initial public offering-hopeful Funlab Group is better bet than Australia's Ardent Leisure.
